questions.question: What is the standard length of a full-size croquet court?

correctTheory.title: Standard Court Dimensions
correctTheory.author: Laws of Association Croquet
correctTheory.key_concepts: Court dimensions, standardization, playing surface
correctTheory.summary: The standard court size was established as 35 yards by 28 yards, with specific requirements for the playing surface and boundary markings.
correctTheory.significance: Standardization of court dimensions was crucial for tournament play and consistent rules across different venues
correctTheory.related_concepts: Boundary marking, hoop placement, yard-line

questions.citation: Laws of Association Croquet, 7th Edition

questions.question: Who is credited with standardizing the rules of croquet in the 1860s?

correctTheory.title: First Standardized Rules of Croquet
correctTheory.author: Walter Jones Whitmore
correctTheory.key_concepts: Rule standardization, competitive play, game formalization
correctTheory.summary: Whitmore published 'Croquet: The Laws and Regulations of the Game,' which became the foundation for modern croquet rules.
correctTheory.significance: First comprehensive rulebook that standardized competitive play
correctTheory.related_concepts: Tournament regulations, game variations, competitive formats

questions.citation: Whitmore, W.J. (1866). Croquet: The Laws and Regulations of the Game

questions.question: What is the 'triple peel'?

answers.answer: Running three hoops with the same ball in one turn
Peeling a ball through its last three hoops while going out
Scoring three points in one turn

correctTheory.title: Advanced Peeling Techniques
correctTheory.author: Various Champions
correctTheory.key_concepts: Peeling, break play, advanced tactics
correctTheory.summary: The triple peel is an advanced tactic where a player peels their partner ball through its last three hoops while completing their own break to win the game.
correctTheory.significance: Demonstrates highest level of tactical play in Association Croquet
correctTheory.related_concepts: Break play, peeling, advanced tactics, game endings

questions.citation: Fulford, R. (2020). Peeling Techniques in Association Croquet

questions.question: In Association Croquet, what happens when a ball is roqueted?

answers.answer: The striker's ball becomes dead on the roqueted ball
The roqueted ball is removed from play
The striker gets an extra turn

correctTheory.title: Roquet and Croquet Strokes
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Roquet, croquet stroke, continuation stroke
correctTheory.summary: After a roquet, the striker's ball becomes dead on the roqueted ball and must take croquet before continuing play.
correctTheory.significance: Fundamental rule that enables tactical play and break building
correctTheory.related_concepts: Dead ball status, croquet stroke, continuation stroke

questions.citation: Laws of Association Croquet, 7th Edition, Law 16

questions.question: What is the optimal order to approach hoops 1 and 2 in a standard break?

correctTheory.title: Break Play Fundamentals
correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Break play, hoop approaches, position play
correctTheory.summary: Approaching hoops 1 and 2 from the south boundary provides the best angle and position for continuing the break.
correctTheory.significance: Essential knowledge for building breaks and maintaining control
correctTheory.related_concepts: Break building, position play, tactical approaches

questions.citation: Croquet Coaching Handbook, Chapter 3: Break Play

questions.question: What scoring system is used in the MacRobertson Shield?

correctTheory.title: International Tournament Formats
correctTheory.author: Croquet Association
correctTheory.key_concepts: Tournament formats, international competition, test matches
correctTheory.summary: The MacRobertson Shield uses a test match format, where teams compete over multiple days in a series of matches.
correctTheory.significance: Most prestigious team event in world croquet
correctTheory.related_concepts: Team competition, international croquet, tournament structure

questions.citation: World Croquet Federation Tournament Regulations

questions.question: Who won the first MacRobertson Shield in 1925?

correctTheory.title: MacRobertson Shield History
correctTheory.author: Croquet Association
correctTheory.key_concepts: International competition, team events, tournament history
correctTheory.summary: The first MacRobertson Shield was won by Australia in 1925, establishing the tournament as the premier international team event in croquet.
correctTheory.significance: Marked the beginning of international team competition in croquet
correctTheory.related_concepts: International croquet, team competition, tournament history

questions.citation: MacRobertson Shield Official Records, Croquet Association Archives

questions.question: What is the correct distance between hoops 1 and 2 on a standard court?

correctTheory.title: Court Setting and Measurements
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Court layout, hoop settings, measurements
correctTheory.summary: The standard distance between hoops 1 and 2 is set at 7 yards, a measurement crucial for proper court setup and consistent play.
correctTheory.significance: Essential for maintaining standardized court layouts worldwide
correctTheory.related_concepts: Court dimensions, hoop placement, setting specifications

questions.citation: Laws of Association Croquet, 7th Edition, Law 2

questions.question: Under current rules, what happens if a ball hits the peg when it is not pegged out?

answers.answer: The ball is removed from play

correctTheory.title: Peg and Rover Ball Rules
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Peg out rules, rover balls, end game
correctTheory.summary: A ball that hits the peg when it is not pegged out causes the turn to end immediately, maintaining the strategic nature of endgame play.
correctTheory.significance: Critical rule for endgame tactics and rover ball management
correctTheory.related_concepts: Rover status, peg out, endgame strategy

questions.citation: Laws of Association Croquet, 7th Edition, Law 38

questions.question: What is the recommended grip pressure for a stop shot?

correctTheory.title: Modern Stop Shot Technique
correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Stop shot, grip pressure, shot control
correctTheory.summary: A medium to light grip pressure is essential for executing stop shots effectively, allowing the mallet to naturally rebound.
correctTheory.significance: Fundamental technique for accurate stop shot execution
correctTheory.related_concepts: Shot types, mallet control, basic techniques

questions.citation: Croquet Coaching Handbook, Chapter 2: Basic Shots

questions.question: In modern Association Croquet, what is the time limit for a standard tournament game?

correctTheory.title: Tournament Time Limits
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Time limits, tournament play, game management
correctTheory.summary: Standard tournament games are typically set at 3 hours, with specific rules for handling endings when time is called.
correctTheory.significance: Essential for tournament organization and play management
correctTheory.related_concepts: Tournament regulations, time management, competitive play

questions.question: In a standard break, what is the recommended position for ball 4 before attempting hoop 1?

correctTheory.title: Break Play Setup
correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Break setup, ball positioning, tactical play
correctTheory.summary: Positioning ball 4 south of hoop 1 provides optimal control and options for continuing the break after running the hoop.
correctTheory.significance: Fundamental principle of break play setup and control
correctTheory.related_concepts: Ball positioning, break control, tactical planning

correctTheory.author: Robert Fulford
correctTheory.key_concepts: Triple peel, delayed peeling, advanced tactics
correctTheory.summary: In a delayed triple peel, positioning the peelee at hoop 4 allows for optimal control and timing of the subsequent peels.
correctTheory.significance: Key strategy for executing advanced peeling breaks
correctTheory.related_concepts: Triple peel, break control, advanced tactics

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of a straight double peel over a standard triple peel?

correctTheory.title: Advanced Peeling Tactics
correctTheory.author: Robert Fulford
correctTheory.key_concepts: Double peel, tactical advantage, game control
correctTheory.summary: A straight double peel allows better control of the opponent's balls throughout the break, providing tactical advantages in game management.
correctTheory.significance: Important tactical variation in advanced play

questions.question: In modern tournament play, what is considered the standard opening with a supershot?

correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Opening tactics, supershot, tactical positioning
correctTheory.summary: The standard supershot opening places the first ball in corner 1 and the second in B-baulk, providing optimal tactical opportunities.
correctTheory.significance: Fundamental opening strategy in modern competitive play
correctTheory.related_concepts: Opening tactics, ball placement, game initiation

questions.question: When performing a triple peel on partner, what is the recommended hoop to attempt the first peel?

correctTheory.title: Triple Peel Execution
correctTheory.author: Robert Fulford
correctTheory.key_concepts: Triple peel, peeling sequence, advanced tactics
correctTheory.summary: Starting the triple peel at 1-back provides the best control and options for completing the remaining peels.
correctTheory.significance: Critical for successful execution of triple peels
correctTheory.related_concepts: Peeling sequence, break control, advanced tactics

questions.citation: Fulford, R. (2020). Peeling Techniques in Association Croquet

questions.question: In modern tournament play with time limits, what is the recommended lead in points before attempting a triple peel?

correctTheory.title: Tournament Tactics and Risk Management
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Tournament tactics, risk management, game strategy
correctTheory.summary: In timed games, attempting a triple peel is recommended only with a substantial lead of at least 8 points to manage risk effectively.
correctTheory.significance: Essential principle for tournament tactics and game management
correctTheory.related_concepts: Risk assessment, game management, competitive strategy

questions.citation: World Croquet Federation Tournament Guidelines 2023

questions.question: In a standard break, what is the optimal position for the pioneer ball at hoop 2?

answers.answer: Directly in front of the hoop
Two yards north of the hoop
One yard east of the hoop
Three yards west of the hoop

correctTheory.title: Pioneer Ball Positioning
correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Break play, pioneer positioning, tactical control
correctTheory.summary: Placing the pioneer two yards north of hoop 2 provides optimal position for continuation after running the hoop.
correctTheory.significance: Critical for maintaining break control and position
correctTheory.related_concepts: Break play, pioneer placement, tactical positioning

questions.question: When executing a triple peel, what is the recommended yard-line position for the peelee before the penultimate peel?

correctTheory.title: Triple Peel Position Play
correctTheory.author: Robert Fulford
correctTheory.key_concepts: Triple peel, position play, advanced tactics
correctTheory.summary: Positioning the peelee on the south yard-line before the penultimate peel provides the best angle and control for completing the triple peel.
correctTheory.significance: Essential for successful execution of the final stages of a triple peel
correctTheory.related_concepts: Peeling tactics, yard-line positioning, endgame control

questions.question: What is the recommended approach when the striker's ball is hampered on a pioneer ball during a break?

answers.answer: Take off to the next pioneer
Use a stop-shot to create separation

correctTheory.title: Hampered Ball Management
correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Break control, hampered shots, tactical recovery
correctTheory.summary: Using a stop-shot to create separation when hampered on a pioneer ball maintains break control while establishing better position.
correctTheory.significance: Key technique for managing common break play challenges
correctTheory.related_concepts: Break recovery, shot selection, position play

questions.citation: Croquet Coaching Handbook, Chapter 5: Advanced Break Play

questions.question: When using a jump shot over a dead ball, what is the maximum permitted mallet angle under current rules?

correctTheory.title: Jump Shot Regulations
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Jump shots, mallet angles, tactical shots
correctTheory.summary: The 45-degree limit on jump shots balances tactical possibilities with equipment protection and fair play.
correctTheory.significance: Critical rule for advanced tactical play while maintaining equipment integrity
correctTheory.related_concepts: Equipment rules, advanced shots, tactical options

questions.citation: Laws of Association Croquet, 7th Edition, Law 28

questions.question: In tournament play, what is the recommended tactic when your opponent has a spread triple peel set up with 10 minutes remaining?

correctTheory.title: Time Management Tactics
correctTheory.author: Robert Fulford
correctTheory.key_concepts: Time management, defensive tactics, endgame strategy
correctTheory.summary: Forcing defensive boundary play can disrupt a triple peel attempt while maximizing time usage in critical endgame situations.
correctTheory.significance: Essential tactic for managing time pressure in tournament endgames
correctTheory.related_concepts: Time management, defensive play, tournament tactics

questions.question: What is the optimal mallet weight for executing stop-shot peels in modern competitive play?

correctTheory.title: Equipment Optimization for Advanced Play
correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Equipment selection, shot execution, technical optimization
correctTheory.summary: A mallet weight of 2.5-3.0 pounds provides optimal control and feedback for executing precise stop-shot peels.
correctTheory.significance: Equipment choice directly impacts advanced shot execution

questions.question: When attempting a triple peel from 1-back, what is the recommended position for the striker's ball before the first peel?

answers.answer: Three feet behind at an angle
Directly in front of the peelee

correctTheory.title: Triple Peel Position Control
correctTheory.author: Robert Fulford
correctTheory.key_concepts: Peeling technique, position control, advanced tactics
correctTheory.summary: Positioning the striker's ball three feet behind at an angle provides optimal control for both the peel and subsequent rush.
correctTheory.significance: Critical for maintaining control throughout the triple peel sequence
correctTheory.related_concepts: Peeling angles, rush positioning, break control

questions.citation: Fulford, R. (2020). Peeling Techniques in Association Croquet

questions.question: In a three-ball ending, what is the recommended tactic when you have two balls near rover and opponent's ball is in corner 4?

answers.answer: Set up a cross-wire at penultimate

correctTheory.title: Advanced Endgame Tactics
correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Endgame strategy, three-ball endings, tactical control
correctTheory.summary: Setting up a cross-wire at penultimate provides the best control and prevents the opponent from gaining an attacking position.
correctTheory.significance: Key tactic for controlling the endgame in three-ball situations
correctTheory.related_concepts: Endgame control, wiring tactics, position play

questions.citation: Croquet Coaching Handbook, Chapter 6: Advanced Endings

questions.question: What is the primary consideration when deciding between a stop-shot and roll shot for a pioneer ball placement?

correctTheory.title: Pioneer Ball Control
correctTheory.author: Coaching Manual
correctTheory.key_concepts: Shot selection, break planning, tactical positioning
correctTheory.summary: The choice between stop-shot and roll shot should primarily be based on the desired positions of both balls for the next phase of the break.
correctTheory.significance: Fundamental principle for maintaining break control and position
correctTheory.related_concepts: Break control, shot selection, position play
